key_points: The Biden Administration plans to make COVID-19 vaccinations for kids ages 5-11 convenient, accessible, and free if authorized by the FDA and CDC.
Currently, 2 in 3 eligible individuals, 189 million Americans, are fully vaccinated - up from 2 million at the start of Biden's presidency.
The administration is preparing for the potential authorization of the first COVID-19 vaccine for children ages 5-11 by the FDA and CDC.
Vaccination for children ages 5-11 will depend on the independent FDA and CDC process, with plans to begin shortly after final CDC recommendation.
States, Tribes, and territories will play a significant role in the rollout, with federal support including full reimbursement for vaccination operations.
The Administration has procured enough vaccine for the country's 28 million children ages 5-11, pending FDA authorization.
Vaccination sites will include doctors' offices, hospitals, pharmacies, community health centers, and school- and community-based sites.
Over 25,000 pediatric and primary care provider sites will offer vaccinations, with efforts to increase the number of providers enrolled.
A partnership with the Children's Hospital Association will set up vaccination sites in over 100 children's hospital systems across the country.
Children's hospitals will work to make vaccines accessible in trusted, family-friendly settings, and provide information to parents.
